S tudent Life 7 FIGHT ON Trojans, young and not so young, gather omecoming is a memorable event for Trojans, both students and alumni. Although many alumni come to other football games, Homecoming gears itself specifically in welcoming back Trojans who have graced the campus in the past. For about a week before the big Homecoming game, the campus was transformed to prepare for the big bash. Bike racks! were removed; tents were set up, areas were roped off, all in preparation for the big day. On Saturday morning, the USC campus took on a large fes­ tive carnival atmosphere. Children were playing football, hop­ ing to be the next Carson Palmer. Cardinal and Gold stream balloons danced around the center of campus. A large computer made of balloons sat in the fountain across from the Student Union, reminding the visitors of the great stride USC has taken technologically. And to keep things safe and fun for all on the crisp autumn day, DPS made its rounds, ensuring that everyone had a good, safe time. Homecoming also gave alumni groups a chance to reunite and sell school spirit. From the Trojan Affiliates selling holiday gifts to the Trojan Club of the San Fernando Valley selling stuffed Traveler toys, all had the same common goal of sharing happy memories and school spirit. But alumni were not the only ones with booths. Both fra­ ternities and sororities spent much time and effort to set up Homecoming booths. Alpha Delta Pi, decked out in Mastercard spoof t-shirts, teamed up with Delta Chi, setting up a BBQ and bar. Samantha Lim, an undeclared freshman and AD Pi said that Homecoming was "a chance to bond with sisters and meet new people." Becky Libby, a broadcast journalism sophomore and AD Pi agreed. "It's great getting to experience USC's awesome tradi­ tion of homecoming." Campus organizations also added to the festive mood. USC Pepsters, an alumni-sponsored group that serve as university ambassadors, held a booth dedicated to the entire Trojan fam­ ily. Brooke Hardy, a sophomore majoring in communication, said that the booth was mainly for the young kids, full of face painting, arts and crafts, and other fun activities. Andrew Compton, a sophomore majoring in public policy, and Ashley Mawhorter, a senior majoring in business, made sure that the 8 Student Life @ USC kids who came to the booth did not leave without paint on their faces or cookies and candy in their hands. Overall, only happy faces populated the campus before the big Homecoming game. It was a great time to reminisce with old friends and make new ones. No matter if the fans were eight or 80, everyone was there to cheer the football team and to have fun. This road trip away from campus is the greatest tradition USC has and as students left the USC area, it quickly became a ghost town. Trojans utilized a variety of means for transportation to northern California - cars, airplanes, trains, and even motorhomes. At the end of the six-hour drive people found lodging with family, friends, or at some hotel nearby the Fisherman's Wharf. Some bay area Trojans decided to visit and share their home with friends from school. Most students arrived Friday night and San Francisco bars and nightclubs saw an influx of Trojans. Other students de­ cided to have a nice quiet night on the town, shopping and en­ joying some of the restaurants. Saturday was the big day for the Trojans. Students who did not attend the game watched from a sports bar or decided to explore the scenic bay area. The Haight and Ashbury district, Pier 39, Lombard Street, and the Golden Gate Bridge were places where many Trojans crossed paths. "I like the fact that I walked through the streets of San Fran­ cisco, a place I have never been to, and see all these people I know from school, " said Jon J uffe, an undeclared freshmen. Saturday afternoon's football game against Stanford was an opportunity for USC to post its first conference win. The crowd went through a roller coaster of emotions but remained spirited throughout. The Trojans led by a score of 30-20 with only a few minutes remaining. However Stanford rallied and were victori­ ous in the end 32-30. Although the loss was sad, it did not dampen students' spirits. The culmination of the weekend was Saturday night, when students let loose and spent time in a completely different set­ ting away from school. The relief of pressure from school is another reason the annual trip is such a popular event. People go not just to watch the game, but to get away. Students were al­ most guaranteed a good time. Some Trojans enjoyed a healthy dose of San Francisco nightlife, electing to enjoy the party scene. Jessica Pishney, a sophomore majoring in social psychol­ ogy said, "I not only saw San Francisco but I traveled to Sacra­ mento with friends . I like northern California, it is a good break from my home on the east coast and from southern California." The ride home on Sunday was long and tiring. Students were fatigued from the game and had to return to campus to get ready for classes on Monday. But in the end it was worthwhile to make the long trip. Students came out of the dorms, off of 28th Street and into Hahn Plaza for a week of concerts, competitions, prizes, movies, inter­ national food, and dancing to pump up Trojans before the big game on November 18. But before the football players ever stepped onto the field, other competitions were going on involving sister teams and organizations from both universities. The schools' newspaper staffs and marching band members played football blood bowls of their own. However, the rivalry was extremely strong and destructive this year when more than $20,000 worth of band equipment was taken from UCLA's equipment truck during a flag football game the weekend before the big game. The equip­ ment was found the next day in the yard of an apartment com­ plex near 28th Street and Orchard Avenue. "I think pranks are great if they don't hurt or harm any­ body," Cynthia Cherrey, USC assistant vice president of Stu­ dent Affairs told the Daily Trojan. "This was harmful to the UCLA band. This whole thing is a poor reflection on our uni­ versity." Pranks and other traditions had always marked the week before the game, but one tradition that Student Senate banned in 1997 has never been witnessed by current USC students, not even this year's graduating senior class. UCLA still has the "Burning of the Trojan Horse," but USC ended the annual "Burning of the Bruin" when the Black Student Union com­ mented that the tradition resembled a lynching and was offen­ sive to African-Americans. Though the actual burning of the Bruin is unlikely to ever return, there is the possibility that a bonfire may take its place in the future. One tradition that has stood the test of time is the guarding of Tommy Trojan by the Trojan Knights. The members of this male spirit organization spend each night of Troy Week pro­ tecting Tommy from being splattered by coats of blue and yel­ low paint. On the last night of the week, Save Tommy Nite, more students join the Knights in Hahn Plaza for carnival ac­ tivities and performances. This year's Save Tommy Nite fea­ tured performances by the Sirens, the SoCal Vocals, the Fly Girls dance team and three student bands: Goba Listik, Listen, and Dominion Mandate. LOOKING Students make ready for life after college W ide-eyed freshmen flooded across Trousdale Parkway, cruising from table to table, grabbing the assortment of free pens, key chains, and toys. Ambitious seniors looked to catch the eye of a potential employer, ready and eager to head off into the working world. The middle of campus was completely overrun with students and business representatives. It was the scene of the fall career fair. The fair, which is staged by the Career Planning and Place­ ment Center, is a day when over 190 companies invade the cam­ pus hoping to recruit USC students. It is a chance for students to meet with various companies and gather information. about possible career paths. "I wanted to see what opportunities were available to me," naidAngelo DeSantis, a senior international relations major, who was among the many eager students. "I was checking out the field," he said. The event is held each semester, and attracts over 2,000 un­ dergraduate and graduate students from all majors and disci- plines. With various companies, including some large consult­ ing firms, new dot-corns, and various advertising and public re­ lations companies, there is bound to be something of interest for everyone. "We really try to pull in all kinds of different companies, not just engineering and business, but also non-profit, educational, and the entertainment industry who are looking for qualified people," said Ann Vedro, the Career Planning and Placement Center's assistant director of employee relations. For students who wanted to live out their X-files fantasies, the FBI and CIA were seeking new agents to recruit during the fair. The career fair is actually one of the many components of the Career Planning and Placement Center. Other programs that help students find their dream jobs include an online campus­ recruiting program, career counseling sessions, and a library of career guidance literature. Vedro said the purpose of the career fair component is "to bridge the gap for students between their majors, being in school and working. And one of the stepping stones to that is to bring the folks here who can hire and tell students about the jobs." Many of the larger academic units on campus, such as busi­ ness and engineering, also hold separate job fairs in addition to the larger, general one. These larger fairs cater more to special­ ized fields of study. Students meet company representatives and build a base for a possible job. When the career fair day rolls around, students scramble to get their resumes spell checked, suits dry-cleaned, shoes shined, and last minute jitters out of their systems before embarking on a few hours that could affect the rest of their lives. For some this is a nerve-racking and anxious day, but for DeSantis it is a part of the college experience. "It's good practice for interviews, fact-finding for jobs, and making the first impression. I just treat it like a big cocktail party, so there's no pressure or anything." II GUIDES AROUND THE - - un1vers1 New signs and a new way to enter campus U pperclassmen realize that freshmen receive the most benefit from two very recent additions to our constantly changing campus. The university has installed a main entrance into the Univer­ sity Park Campus and added new signs on the outside of each university building. The addi­ tions help all visitors, students, and staff through our enormous campus, but especially those who have never lived or worked on the campus before - freshmen. On the first day of school everyone is running around cam­ pus hurrying to avoid tardiness. These new red, gold, and silver signs display the university logo, state the building's full name, street address, and abbreviation. These signs provide a sleek new look to campus, and offer a unifying visual theme to all buildings - from the older science and engineering buildings to the newest additions on campus. The abbreviation aspect is extremely useful, as students no longer have to worry about finding out what VKC and GFS ~ludd 1--:l a II actually stand for, they can just look for the three-letter designa­ tion code on the sign. This is especially useful for freshmen who don't know what some building abbreviations represent. "Finally I can make my first class of the semester," said Jonathan Alcantar, a junior majoring in Cinema-Television. The second addition that drew students' attention was the new main entrance to campus. The gate is located near the cor­ ner of Figueroa and Exposition Blvd. This beautiful entranceway was designed to enhance the USC experience for visitors. Doug Moody, a sophomore majoring in business said, "I think that it is only appropriate that a university as picturesque as ours has an entrance to parallel its beauty." The entrance was constructed during the 2000 spring and summer semesters. As people drive through the entrance, they are met by a circular bed of red and gold flowers. Farther on, they are greeted by two black metal gates and a causeway of red brick. The attendant booth lights up the surrounding area and the sidewalks are lined with trees and small, narrow pools of water. The path continues on toward the Alumni House. It seems fitting that the new gate leads directly to that particular build­ ing, since USC's alumni are so involved with the inner work­ ings of the university. The new gate is more expansive than the other gates around campus. It is both regal and imposing, as opposed to the other gates, which were built primarily for functionality. Since USC was recently designated "College of the Year" by Time maga­ zine, it is only appropriate that the campus beauty be enhanced by the new entrance. "The campus really looks classier with the new gate," said Ericka Menick, the customer service representative at Fluor Tower. Guides Around the University 19 PRESENTS Presidential Hopeful and Presidential Parent T he Republican Party came to the university in full force in March of 2000 with lectures by Senator John McCain (R-Arizona) and former President George Bush. McCain stopped by USC on his campaign College Tour with CNBC's political television program "Hardball." Bush's speech was given as one of the President Sample's Distinguished Lecture Series. Though McCain eventually lost the GOP presidential nomi­ nation to Texas governor George W. Bush, McCain's interview with the show's host Chris Matthews showed that the former candidate's main concerns were in bringing about party reform and inspiring young voters to become involved in politics. "The whole reason why I'm running for President of the United States is to connect young people again to their govern­ ment," McCain said. He said that he wanted to energize the younger generation and to get them "involved in the political process so that they feel they have a stake in it." McCain's solution for the unmotivated, apathetic youth was to reform the Republican Party and reform politics in general. He pointed to the fact that the GOP has lost the last two presi­ dential and congressional elections. McCain theorized that this might be because many people have begun to view the GOP as an "exclusionary" party, thus reform is the only way out of the cycle. George Bush Sr., during his speech in Bovard, also spoke to the audience about staying involved in politics. He went on to praise USC students for their current involvement in the com­ munity by mentioning the recent Time magazine award, (USC, College of the Year). He emphasized the importance of being a part of the extremely prosperous Pacific Rim and staying in­ volved with world politics. "You don't have to be President to help build a better future. You don't have to be the First Lady to help lift the lives of oth­ ers. All you have to do is care, roll up your sleeves, get off the sidelines and claim one of society's problems as your own," Bush said. Bush commented on southern California's invaluable loca­ tion along the Pacific Rim. After leaving the presidency, Bush made frequent visits to Asia. He observed China's booming economy and its growing freedom. He said he encourages trade with China and other Pacific Rim countries. He said the United States could use the Korean work ethic as an example, but that our government "must not listen when the selfish sirens (in Asia) call for isolation and protection." To cater to the diversity of students and their tastes, there were a few new additions at various locations on campus with the Galen Center, Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, and the new Popovich Cyber Cafe. The Galen Center opened its doors last year to cater to the needs of university athletes. It is located west of Heritage Hall, behind the intramural field. During the afternoon, it is open to the campus community with a variety of foods ranging from daily specials, to salads, desserts and sodas. The dining area features two big screen TV's and multiple smaller screens to enhance the sporty ambience. It is also a perfect place to "tail­ gate" before USC home football games, and many students take advantage of its easy access before games to do just that. Krispy Kreme doughnuts are delivered fresh each day and offer a variety of choices, including weekly specials. Often the Krispy Kreme eatery is shut down by noon, since the doughnuts are so popular and sell out quickly. Omar Sosa, a senior majoring in filmic writing, said "I sim­ ply can't face a morning without having a doughnut and some coffee. Krispy Kreme's are great." Located near the new Gate 2 entrance, it also provides a place for business students to grab a soda or a snack. In attendance was Katherine B. Loker, who was honored for her $2 million gift, the largest donation ever to the athletic department by a single person, which will make construction of the stadium a possibility. "Our ambition is always to be the best athletically, as well as academically," said President Steven Sample. "That requires that we have top-flight athletic facilities. If we want our ath­ letes to be competitive at the highest level, we owe them the resources to achieve that level of athletic excellence. This new facility will go a long way toward reaching that goal." Soon men in yellow hard hats showed up on site with their tools and cranes to improve the track. In the past, the track had two entrances on the east and west sides. On the west side of the track, there was an area that consisted of a few benches for sit­ ups, push-ups, or weight lifting, as well as a few pull-up bars. Many athletes came onto the track either before or after going to the Lyon Center to do some running and conditioning. It was common to see people do pull-ups and stretches in that area and then proceed to run laps on the track. The new stadium will provide new features beneficial to athletes, coaches and fans. It has offices, locker rooms, and a team meeting area for athletes and coaches. There is also a gal­ lery for the top rated track team to display its awards and memo­ rabilia. In addition, the new bleacher system above these facili­ ties allows up to 3,000 spectators to enjoy track meets in com­ fort. Fittingly, the facility is being built during USC track and field's 100th anniversary - the perfect tribute to a heritage that includes 28 NCAA team championships, 118 individual titles, 40 Olympic gold medals and 61 world records. Joe King, a junior majoring in petroleum engineering said, "I think it's a good idea that they're putting more stands in be­ cause there's not enough seating on the track. As it is, the seat­ ing is piddly and I would really like to go watch the team. And as good as the track team is, they deserve more recognition be­ cause they don't get enough in Heritage Hall." The idea of the Loker Track Stadium originated with the Athletic Department.
